bibl.note: This is a letter dated Aug. 12, 1840 from Robert Woods to his son James. Robert is giving James advice, mostly about how to pursue a career, and about school. He also mentions the importance of good health, and his opinion that his own health is in a permanent decline. Robert also writes how much he is concerned for the welfare of all his children, James included.

div1.p: Your note of the 10 Inst Coming are in view of the stock of westwood is receivd , for which I feel much gratified , I am of opinion however , you have valued a portion of yours too high, but this is only a matter of opinion,

Your invayed is neatly made out and goes to show that you take Some intrest in forming and improving your hand writing , this impression is extremely pleasant to me, as your health, prospects, and happiness mostly depend on your course of conduct while young, your health has been Such as not to admit of a liberal education, you will as a matter of course, have to turn your attention to Farming or Planting, all proffessions, ( Lawyers, Doctors, Farmg. , & Plantg. must study theirtheir different professions and become fond of them or interested in them, before they Can be made profitable or even plesant, should your health continue good untill the and of Sept would it not be well for you to Seat sit in to at School again, I feel very desirous you should do so, if your health will alow of it, you can improve yourself very much in this way, by attend ⁁ ing School
at your present age, conected with your farming operations, reading history, writing ? at home reasonably , you will will in a few years be a good English scholar & be qualified for all usefull business, such as Farming Planting Merchandizing all this , will require in a young man, Some and energy, which I am inclined to think you can perform, mostly I consider trash and ought not to be read by any one,

My health is very little improved, nor have I much idea that it will ever be much better than it now is, I have no idea that I shall live long, in a very short time I must leave you, & my interest for your welfare and for that of your brothers & sisters is beyond all any thing that I can express on paper, the Solisitude of a Parent for the welfare of a child, you can form no idea
I may take a notion to gow home in a few ⁁ days — or I may not, much will depend on my findings on Saturday,
Old Gray is very sick, I fear we shall loose him, our Company has nearly all left for the Convention
my Love to your mother & children
